executive_summary: Despite a brief disruption during the COVID-19 pandemic, the Pediatricians industry has grown at a healthy pace over the past five years. Funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) has increased allowing for increased access to pediatric care, while a rising number of children aged nine and younger has further expanded the industry's market. While the number of births per year has been on the decline, immigration has kept the total number of children in the US from declining, keeping demand for pediatric care stable. As a result of these trends, over the five years to 2024, industry revenue is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2.4% to $18.3 billion, including an expected 0.4% increase in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pediatric Care Has Surged Out of the Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Like many healthcare providers, pediatricians were limited in their ability to see in-person patients during the pandemic. Patients either delayed nonessential care or switched appointments to virtual. Unlike other industries impacted by the pandemic, when in-person restrictions were lifted pediatricians saw patient volumes and revenue quickly recover and exceed pre-pandemic levels.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Children's Health Insurance Program Continues to Support Industry Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A significant portion of pediatric patients receive health insurance through Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). These programs, funded by the Federal and State governments provide health insurance to low-income children. However, while revenue growth will be healthy, the healthcare labor shortage will contribute to higher wages and decreased profit. In 2029, profit margins are expected to continue falling to 13.3% of revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE HEALTHCARE LABOR SHORTAGE WILL CONTINUE TO THREATEN PEDIATRICIANS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In the coming years, the factors that have driven employees away from the Healthcare sector are not likely to wane. While efforts have been made to address healthcare worker burnout, the number of employees entering the sector continues to fall. Pediatrician patient capacity will be limited over the next five years as the labor shortage leads to some pediatrician's offices being forced to operate with a limited staff.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE DECLINING NUMBER OF BIRTHS THREATENS PEDIATRICIANS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: For much of the past decade, the number of births per year has been declining due to demographic and social changes including people getting married later and increased labor market participation among women. This trend is expected to continue over the coming years as rising utility and rent costs will make child rearing financially difficult for many young couples. With fewer births, the number of children in the US will decline, lowering demand for pediatric healthcare. However, immigration is expected to keep the number of children at a healthy level in the US, reducing volatility for pediatricians.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry provide medical care for children and teens under the age of 18.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Number of children aged nine and younger
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: Government insurance has grown the market for pediatric healthcare despite shifting demographics. Even as the number of births declines, increased access to health insurance allows more patients to receive care.
The Healthcare labor shortage threatens pediatrician's patient capacity. Even when pediatrician's offices offer higher salaries, some offices are struggling to fully staff their operations.
Regulation remains high for pediatric healthcare. Like most healthcare providers, pediatricians are required to maintain medical records and provide care in a clean and safe environment.
Medicaid expansion has grown CHIP funding, supporting pediatric care. As more children gain access to government health insurance, the market for pediatric care grows.
General pediatric care continues to be the mainstay of the industry. Young children need consistent healthcare to support their growth and development.
Pediatric specialties continue to emerge and create opportunities for pediatricians. Advances in pediatric medicine create opportunities to specialize in niche parts of the Healthcare sector.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Parents typically provide health insurance coverage for their children through employer-sponsored and non-group insurance plans. The vast majority of this coverage is employer-sponsored, so as unemployment has declined, insurance coverage has grown.

The Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) provides health coverage for low-income children and adolescents through Medicaid and separate state-run programs. While reimbursement rates are lower for public health insurance programs, CHIP allows pediatricians to provide healthcare to low-income children while still generating healthy revenue and profit.

products_and_services.product_description: While the vast majority of pediatric care is general care and annual physician visits, more than half of pediatric patients are below the age of 12. This breakdown is by design and will continue this way because younger children and babies need more regular healthcare to track development and prevent later health issues.

While patients are able to visit a pediatrician until they reach the age of 21, patient numbers decline with age, as family care physicians are able to take over as adolescents get closer to adulthood. Female patients typically begin seeing an OBGYN around age 13-15. For many parents, this signals the time to shift their child to a general care physician.

As research into pediatric health continues to improve and access to healthcare expands, there has been growing demand for specialized medicine in the pediatric healthcare space. Children's hospitals are in constant need of pediatric cardiologists, oncologists, hematologists and other specialized pediatricians. Highly populated cities also have need for pediatric critical care specialists. Pediatric genecology has recently emerged as a growing specialty among OBGYNs. 13-to-18-year-olds have different health needs than adult women, and are likely to be more comfortable working with physicians that specialize in their age group.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of Children Aged Nine and Younger
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Children aged nine and younger represent the largest market for the Pediatricians industry. While pediatricians can provide care to all people under the age of 21, demand is strongest among young children since adolescents may choose to visit general care physicians. As the number of children increases, so does demand for pediatric care.

Total health expenditure measures the dollar amount spent on healthcare products and services within a year. This metric serves as a proxy for the overall demand for healthcare in the US. As health expenditure rises, so does demand for pediatric services. Consistently rising health expenditure presents an opportunity for pediatricians.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Federal Funding for Medicare and Medicaid
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Many children in the US receive health insurance through the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). CHIP is a division of Medicaid that offers health insurance to low-income children. As funding for CHIP grows, more children can receive pediatric healthcare, and low-income families are more likely to pursue pediatric care, thus supporting industry revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of People with Private Health Insurance
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of people with private health insurance measures the number of people with either employer-sponsored or non-group health insurance. More than half of pediatric patients are covered through some form of private health insurance, so as private health insurance enrollment grows, so does industry revenue. Changes in health insurance enrollment pose a threat to pediatricians.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Education costs have continued to rise
barriers_points.barrier_description: Barriers to entry have grown as education costs have continued to rise. The cost of obtaining a medical degree has continued to grow, deterring some young adults from pursuing a career in medicine.

Homeopathic and alternative medicine have begun to threaten traditional pediatric healthcare. It's becoming more common for parents to explore alternatives to western medicine when caring for their children.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs driven up by COVID-19 pandemic
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The COVID-19 pandemic drove up purchase costs through heightened medical supply costs

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Healthcare labor shortage driving wage growth
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The healthcare labor shortage has driven wage growth. High education costs, difficult work and a rapidly aging population have all contributed to a shortage of qualified healthcare professionals, particularly nurses.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and patent concentration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The Pediatricians industry is not typically characterized by robust levels of revenue volatility. Pediatric healthcare is a necessity for most families, so revenue normally grows at a steady pace. 2020 saw one of the most significant revenue decline in the industry's history as many pediatricians could not see patients in person during the height of the pandemic.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Pent-up demand after pandemic led to surge
volatility_points.volatility_description: As the pandemic passed, pent-up demand for pediatric care resulted in a massive surge in revenue as the industry quickly returned to pre-pandemic levels.

FAQs.question: What was the impact of the pandemic on the pediatric care industry?
FAQs.answer: As the pandemic passed, pent-up demand for pediatric care resulted in a massive surge in revenue as the industry quickly returned to pre-pandemic levels.

FAQs.question: What happened to revenue growth after the initial post-pandemic surge?
FAQs.answer: The following year, the revenue growth returned to a stable place.
